reviews.review_msg: Course specifically focused on Indigenous Health. Dr. Kelm is very caring and reasonable with her grading. Some criteria are vague, but if clarifications are needed, Dr. Kelm was more than happy to answer e-mails/office hours/talk after class. Primarily had to do research projects but had enough time to do them. She gave good advice along the way.

Admission tickets that you hand in before tutorials and if you forget to do it the 2nd time you won't get participation marks for that day (total worth: 20% of final grade). Lectures are extremely dry, quizzes are short but also stupid because she barely mentions quiz content in lecture. Grading criteria sucks. Not recommended as a GPA booster.

She's a passionate prof. However, she doesn't have any lecture slides for you because all of her "lecture slides" are just pictures. She never recognizes how fast she is talking yet she expects everyone to write down everything she says because what she says will be on the pop quiz. Textbook won't help you.

Caring and informative professor, Dr. Kelm is great for those willing to engage in class. Criteria for grading can be vague at times, but she makes it up with her support and clarification in office hours. Accommodating to extensions if needed. Few assignments, participation in seminar is important to get high grades
Super nice and passionate about her field.

Lectures were extremely dry. Assignments had little to do with the lectures; they could be done without attending a single one. Marking criteria was vague and hard to follow. Readings were usually bland and unnecessarily long. Sweet and caring when help is needed, but not a great lecturer.

She is a lovely lady, but certainly not my favourite prof. Lectures were disorganized, (often) irrelevant, and difficult to follow. It also seemed like she tried to use up class time by having various historians come in and speak- only one of which I found relevant to the course material. Also irrelevant group work. Overall, very mediocre course
She walks around class all the times. she has a straight voice. this course is relatively easy but lots of reading.

Very passionate. Lectures weren't useful, as a lot of time was spent reading the text or conducting group discussions, which isn't going very productive with a class like this. Text book is necessary for tutorial participation and little else. Class doesn't really teach much, if you have basic writing skills you're likely guaranteed a B minimum.

It was really hard to follow her lectures and understand what was important. She wastes a lot of time in lectures by dividing the class to do group discussions. Some of her assignments were really pointless.

What annoyed me about this class is a lot of times we would spend 5-15 minutes per lecture reading our textbook (first class I've ever seen that). Since this was my only class on Tuesdays, I just stopped going & listened to the audio. She seems to really like history and has a clear voice. Lots of discussing, but I prefer more traditional lectures.

Kelm's class is hard to stay awake in. When I approached her with questions, she was irritated and seemed like she wanted me out of her face fast. Her TA Morag is a HARD marker and isnt very kind and acts as if you are inferior.

although she is very approachable and friendly, and is interested in subject matter, lectures don't match notes/powerpoints and lectures are at too rapid a pace.  also needs to supervise ta's more as her expectations and ta's expectations are different
interesting and helpful.  She LOVES what she teaches and it shows!

Mary Ellen was a fantastic professor who really opens the door up for people to challenge how they view North American history. She is a very justifiable marker and will provide as much guidance as you need, especially due to the fact that some Indigenous history is not covered or easily accessible. I would take another class with her.
I found her to be an expert on her subject and a good lecturer. Student questions and participation are encouraged, and workload is fair.
